TF025117-PHRD-PROVINCIAL HEALTH PROJ. II,TF052893-JSDF-EAP: PREVENTION AND

            HEALTH PROJECT II

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Provincial Health
            Project for Indonesia are as follows: outcome was
            unsatisfactory, risk to the development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also rated
            as unsatisfactory. Some of the lessons learned included: 1)
            providing Bank funding for decentralized activities entails
            considerable risk to project success in a situation where
            lower level entities, in this case primarily districts, do
            not have clear indications of what specific functions they
            can or cannot undertake, particularly if these functions are
            not set forth in legislation. Some districts, like Subang in
            West Java were successful in developing local workforce and
            financing policies because of the dynamic and resourceful
            leadership, and the willingness to mobilize required
            technical assistance either from the province level or from
            consultants; 2) projects will meet difficulties if authority
            is decentralized without provision of specific standards for
            implementing these authorities. One of the major
            frustrations of provinces and districts was being given
            authority in the laws for undertaking general functions that
            could be used to foster reforms but then not having the
            ability to set standards for ensuring that these functions
            could be properly performed. Nevertheless, North Sumatera
            and West Java had some progress in their reform efforts by
            learning from and adopting some of the reform ideas
            developed by the Yogyakarta Province, although
            administrative problems prevented the provinces from
            achieving more results. This is made possible by the good
            cross learning environment established between first and
            second Provincial Health Project (PHP I and II); and 3) in
            situations of great institutional change and turbulence,
            reform oriented projects should set priorities for which
            reforms should be taken in what sequence. Attempting to
            implement too wide a scope of reforms at the same time
            places a large burden on project implementers operating in
            situations of great uncertainty. If the Bank is also well
            out in front of the client in terms of the how well the
            client understands the proposed reforms and how they can be
            best addressed, the implementation difficulties are only compounded.
